text: I'm just hearing Nick Timothy has
resigned that is what we just heard in
the last few moments
Nick Timothy one of two special advisers
to Sarita may what I was about to tell
you was that we had heard our assistant
Adela Norman Smith had that
understanding in the last couple of
hours that a lot of senior conservatives
were demanding that to resume fact her
two chief advisors Nick Timothy is one
fiona hill is the other they had said
that she must get rid of them by the end
of the weekend otherwise they would seek
to instigate a leadership contest on
Monday that is what the demand that have
been made in the last few hours so we
are just hearing in the last few moments
that Nick Timothy has resigned we wait
to hear whether there is any development
around fiona hill but that's what we've
heard in the last few moments one of the
two has gone norman yes and i think
we're getting a sense of how mrs. Mae is
now seeking to shore up her position
because clearly that was there was that
ultimatum issued by Tory MPs in effect
saying sac mr. Timothy and Fiona Hill or
you will face a leadership challenge now
mr. Timothy has voluntarily resigned
saying he takes responsibility for his
role in the election campaign although
disputing that he was responsible for
the very very controversial social care
policy which was so widely criticized
saying that this was a policy devised
over many months it wasn't his pet
project it wasn't something which he
particularly drew up but I think we get
a sense now of the operation within
number 10 to shore up mrs. Mayes
position because mr. Timothy and miss
Hill have almost become a lightning rods
for the criticism of mrs. May and in
particular they are directly blamed by
many conservative MPs for the flawed
election campaign the manifesto for what
was described this morning by one
insider as the dysfunctional atmosphere
inside number 10 and it was put to me
that their departure was a litmus test
of mrs. Mayes readiness to change to
show that she got it she understood the
implications
the election night and the need to
change your style to be more inclusive
collaborative and pathetic if you like
and there was a view that as long as
these two individuals who've been with
Mrs May through thick and thin ultra
loyal sort of Bulldogs on behalf of mrs.
may if they stayed beside her then there
was no likelihood of mrs. may style
fundamentally changing one has now gone
and I suspect there must be a question
mark about whether the other two and the
other Fiona Hill will follow suit and
just as you are speaking Norman in fact
the Press Association reporting that
Fiona Hill has resigned as well so the
Press Association saying that she has
also gone and that then Norman that is
what those senior conservatives that
you've been hearing from have wanted
yeah it's amazing how cookie vents have
moved and I think that probably
underlines just how fragile
mrs. Mae's position is she cannot afford
in any way to risk facing down these
Tory MPs the idea that they might not
perhaps launch the leadership challenge
she knows the threat
